title: How can I run C code from inside Sublime Text 2?

cells.data:
The Build System has changed slightly for Sublime Text 2 (http://sublimetext.info/docs/en/...).  Instead of key-value pairs, the sublime-build files are now JSON (like all the other config files).  

Assuming you have a Makefile, by default, ST2 should already compile your code using that. It is bad practice to configure the Makefile to both compile & execute your code (what about compilation error handling, unintended code execution, etc).  But luckily, the ST2 build system can help.

  1. Make a new Build System by going to "Tools:Build System:New Build System...".  It should look like this:

    1
2
3

    {
      "cmd": ["make"]
    }
  2. Replace ["make"] with ["make && ./a.out"].  Replace `./a.out` with the path to whatever program you want to actually execute on build.
  3. By default, ST2 does not have access to your path.  So add your normal bash $PATH to the `sublime-build` file and set it to `shell` mode..  

    1
2
3
4
5

    {
      "cmd": ["make && ./a.out"],
      "path": "/usr/bin:/usr/local/bin:...",
      "shell": true
    }


    Replace the path variable with your actual path - a non-working, dummy path is shown above.
  4. Test it.  Stdout/Stderr should be printed to your Sublime Text 2 console as well as any un-silenced Make commands.
  5. Also, if your compilation step takes a while, I suggest using a tool like GrowlNotify to ping you asynchronously upon completion so you can go do other stuff while you wait (like read Quora).
